newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: Former U.S. Black Panther barred from Australia.
newsitem.headline: Former U.S. Black Panther barred from Australia.

text.p: The Australian government on Friday cancelled the visitor visa held by former U.S. Black Panther Lorenzo Ervin, blocking any future attempts by the human rights activist to return to Australia.
A spokesman for the immigration minister said Ervin was believed to have left the country early on Friday.
The government's plan to have Ervin deported earlier this month was foiled when a court ruled there had been a procedural error in the way Ervin's visa was cancelled.
Ervin, convicted in 1969 of hijacking an aircraft from the United States to Cuba, was in Australia for a four-week speaking tour on the invitation of anarchist group Angry People.
Immigration Minister Philip Ruddock said the latest decision was based on Ervin's convictions for air piracy, kidnapping and for the assault of a corrections officer.

"I was satisfied that there has been no pardon amounting to a finding of innocence on these matters," Ruddock said in a statement. "I weighed these convictions against the countervailing factors going to Mr Ervin's good character."
"Having full regard to all these matters, I formed the view that Mr Ervin is not of good character."
Ervin received two life sentences for the 1969 hijacking, but was released from jail in 1983.
The Australian government cancelled Ervin's first visa on the grounds that he had apparently misrepresented his past when he used a different surname when applying for the visa.
Ervin also failed to fill in his passenger entry card indicating that he had been convicted of an offence requiring him to be jailed for more than 12 months.
The government then rejected two new visa applications from Ervin and tried to have him deported, saying it was not in the national interest for a convicted hijacker to stay in Australia.
